text: - Digital transformation in healthcare
is driven by a unique interplay

between health policy
imperatives and reforms
and great advances in technology.
All health systems around the world

are looking at ways to
transform themselves,
to reform themselves.

And most of these reforms
seem to be inspired

by the idea of moving
towards more of a value based
healthcare proposition.

How can we actually deliver
outcomes that matter most
to patients and communities

and how can we activate
patients and carers

and make them real participants
in the healthcare process?

Digital technology is
really seen as a key enabler
of many of those reforms.
eHealth New South Wales is the digital arm

of New South Wales Health,
which in turn is the largest
public health system in Australia.

Our mission is to support
digital transformation

and digital enablement
of our health system.
It looks after 8.2 million residents.

It has 160,000 staff working
across 228 public hospitals
in more than 300 community health centres.

Digital transformation is
already making a big difference

to patient outcomes in
New South Wales Health.
- Some of our early transformation work
has been taking our critical clinical
and corporate applications
and then migrating them up into the cloud.

This allows us to take
advantage of the cloud hosted

technology to better
support the healthcare
of New South Wales citizens.

We've taken eight of our
largest clinical applications

and we have migrated them
up into the AWS cloud space.
For six of those applications,
we've had the privilege of partnering

with our application vendors
to be the first organisation

nationally or globally to
rehost them into the cloud.

- These types of systems
are particularly focusing
on supporting day-to-day clinical care
and making it safer, making more efficient

and also introducing various
types of decision support tools
that are assisting our busy clinicians
with their day to day work.

- The approach we took is to
actually not just do a lift

and shift, but actually refactor
most of our applications
as we've migrated to the cloud.

As a result of that, we've
optimised most of the use

of our applications to use
some of the native offerings
and managed services that are available
in the cloud offering.

We've actually delivered
a lot of improvements

to our services, to the
uptime of our products
and platforms, and also the agility

in the way we deliver those
services and added extra tools
and services on top of those platforms.

Anecdotally, we've had
about 60% uptime improvement

in some of the platforms
have been moved up
into the cloud infrastructure
as part of the re-platforming.
We've also increased the sustainability
in terms of the financial sustainability

by being able to use cloud
infrastructure to spin up

and spin down servers when
they're not being used.
The advantage of that for both clinical

and non-clinical staff
means that our applications
are available more of the time
which means less outages to clinical care.

They're more responsive,
they scale easier.
- eHealth New South Wales is also making
strategic investments, covering things
like refreshing all of our infrastructure

and our core systems in our
data centres to public cloud.

It's investing in our
people by uplifting skills
and investing in innovations,

like advanced analytics
to benefit patient care.

- We recognised early on
that a technical change

with the migration to cloud is
only one piece of the puzzle.
In order to continue to innovate
and make the most of the cloud technology

and the benefits that come with
the digital transformation,

we needed to upskill our staff
to take advantage of that.

The first way we do this
is by encouraging our staff
to go through the Digital Academy.

The Digital Academy
offers training pathways

that allow our staff to
get baseline competencies
in things like cloud technology, DevOps,

continuous improvement,
continuous development,

all these type of skills that
are going to be important

as we go through the
digital transformation.

- The reason we've been able
to move at pace to be agile

is because we have
already had really strong
technology foundations in place

and we also had really, really
strong effective partnerships
with our industry partners and suppliers
who have enabled us through technologies

like Cloud to be able
to very quickly respond

to increasing demands for the
use of digital technology.

- And the team at AWS
feel really privileged
to be one of eHealth strategic partners

in this transformation journey
that they're going through.
They are a unique global leader
in the healthcare provider space

in all the ambitious
work that they're doing
across the org transformation,
the technology transformation,
as well as their investment in skills,

they're making absolute
global leading strides
to deliver modern healthcare
to the citizens of New South Wales.
